conclusion: Analyze the processes depicted in the p-V diagram to determine heat absorption and release.
Process a to b is a vertical line on the p-V diagram indicating constant volume and increasing pressure.
In an isochoric process, work done is zero because there is no change in volume (W = 0).
The change in internal energy (ΔU) is equal to the heat added (Q) since W = 0, therefore Q = ΔU.
Since pressure increases, temperature and internal energy increase, implying heat is absorbed (Q > 0).
Process b to c is a curve on the p-V diagram indicating changes in both pressure and volume.
In an adiabatic process, no heat is exchanged with the surroundings (Q = 0).
The gas does work on the surroundings, and its internal energy decreases as it moves to higher volume and lower pressure.
Process c to d is a vertical line on the p-V diagram indicating constant volume and decreasing pressure.
Again, work done is zero (W = 0) in an isochoric process.
The change in internal energy (ΔU) is equal to the heat released (Q) since W = 0, therefore Q = ΔU.
Since pressure decreases, temperature and internal energy decrease, implying heat is released (Q < 0).
Process d to a is a curve on the p-V diagram indicating changes in both pressure and volume.
No heat is exchanged with the surroundings (Q = 0) in an adiabatic process.
Work is done on the gas, resulting in an increase in internal energy as it moves to lower volume and higher pressure.
Net heat absorbed is the heat absorbed during process a to b.
Net heat released is the heat released during process c to d.
Net change in internal energy over one complete cycle is zero, so net work done is equal to net heat absorbed minus net heat released.
Area enclosed by the cycle on the p-V diagram represents net work done by the gas.
Since the cycle is clockwise, the gas does net positive work on the surroundings.
The amount of heat absorbed during the cycle is greater than the amount of heat released.
